p.s: In the following, I am going to analizeanalyze the dialogue between Walter and Ruth with a special focus on WaltersWalter's dream and how he wants to achieve it.

Walter seems to be really unhappy with his living conditions and status [...] I got a boy who sleeps in the living room [...] and all I got to give him is stories about how rich white people live (l. 41ff.).
He thinks that he is worth less than the white buisnessmenbusinessmen he drives around in his job as a chauffeur without upwards mobility.
So he wants to escape this lower position and be a masculine role model for his son that can offer him anything.

He regrets that he missed a job oppurtunityopportunity once that could have made him independent When [Charlie Atkins] wanted me to go in the dry-cleaning business with him.And now- he's grossing a hundred thousand a year (l. 7f.) he is tired of their life in poorness and thinks that Ruth sees it the same way You tired, ain't you?Tired of everything (l. 11).
But Ruth doesn't react to this Walter, please leave me alone (l. 15).
Even while she basicly has the same wish of better living conditions she delines WaltersWalter's ambitioned buisnessbusiness plans because she thinks his need to make money is way totoo desperate.
WaltersWalter's plan to realize his dream is a liquor store.
He wants to invest the insurance money into buying it and lead it with his friends Bobo and Willy.

This seems really risky because he would even need to bribe somebody for the license Course there's a couple hundreds you got to pay so's you don't spend your life just waiting for them clowns to let your license get approved (l. 29f.).
But WaltersWalter's will of self fulfillmentfulfilment is so strong that committing this crime doesn't seem like a problem for him.
He even glosses over when telling his plans until Ruth realizes it you mean graft? (l. 31) and wants to manipulate her to talk to Mama about it (l. 18).
From Ruth's perspective this is nonsense and an unnecessary risk.
She wants Walter to stop talking Walter- (l. 17) and wants to end the conversation by telling him to eat his eggs Eat your eggs, they gonna be cold (l. 34).
This request can be seen symbolic for the relation of a a man's dreams beeingbeing destroyed by a modest black womenwoman.

Walter takes this personal because his own wife doesn't even support his highly desired lifegoal Man say to his woman: I got me a dream.His woman say: Eat your eggs.[...] I got to change my life, I'm choking to death, baby! (l. 35ff.).

All in all one could say that WaltersWalter's dream is to be independent, escape his depressing life and make money with his own liquor store that gives him back his masculine pride and self fulfillmentfulfilment.
But is stopped by the modest wife that rationally doesn't want to take this risk, because she safely wants to invest it in their life by buying a house what is also Mama's wish.
So in this way WaltersWalter's manipulation of Ruth speaks about her own mothersmother's wish since she is the person the money belongs to.
By needing Allall the money for himself even BeneathasBeneatha's dream of medical school even seems more realistic because it is also selfish but doesn't require all the money.
In this way WaltersWalter's dream is hard and almost impossible to realize but he holds on to it.
